title: How to Make Battery Eliminators

steps.headline: Turn the device off, and remove the battery cells.
steps.description: Recharge or properly dispose of them.

steps.headline: Cut wood dowels into the right size for the battery you're replacing.
steps.description: 1/2" diameter dowel rod will work for AA cells, and 1.25" dowel for D cells. Cut the dowels to about the length of the cell not counting the protruding (+) tip; that will be provided using a screw. You only need two pieces of dowel, whether you're replacing 2, 4, or 8 cells.

steps.headline: Drill a pilot hole into the center of one end, smaller than the screw you'll be using.
Screw a small wood screw, preferably with a head that most resembles the positive tip of the cell, into the hole you just drilled.
Strip the wire from the positive (+) end of your power supply, and loop it around the screw.
steps.description: For a better connection, use a crimp terminal instead.

steps.headline: Tighten the screw onto the wire or terminal.
Repeat the steps for the negative (-) terminal.
Double-check your polarity with a meter if you have one.
Mark the dowels with red and/or "+" for positive and black and/or "-" for negative, to avoid dangerous and costly mix-ups!
Insert the dowels into the device, with correct polarity (see Tips), and turn it on.

tyn: Various lengths and diameters of dowel rod
Pieces of wire, 18 gauge or larger (the lower-numbered gauge, the larger the wire)
Power supplies: solar panels, car batteries, old wall warts, etc.
text: Turn the device off, and remove the battery cells. Recharge or properly dispose of them. Cut wood dowels into the right size for the battery you're replacing. 1/2" diameter dowel rod will work for AA cells, and 1.25" dowel for D cells. Cut the dowels to about the length of the cell not counting the protruding (+) tip; that will be provided using a screw. You only need two pieces of dowel, whether you're replacing 2, 4, or 8 cells. Drill a pilot hole into the center of one end, smaller than the screw you'll be using.  Screw a small wood screw, preferably with a head that most resembles the positive tip of the cell, into the hole you just drilled. Don't tighten it yet. Strip the wire from the positive (+) end of your power supply, and loop it around the screw. For a better connection, use a crimp terminal instead. Tighten the screw onto the wire or terminal.  Repeat the steps for the negative (-) terminal.  Double-check your polarity with a meter if you have one.  Mark the dowels with red and/or "+" for positive and black and/or "-" for negative, to avoid dangerous and costly mix-ups!  Insert the dowels into the device, with correct polarity (see Tips), and turn it on.
